**Frequency and Timing:**

Aim to do strength training exercises 2-3 times a week, with at least one day of rest in between. This allows your muscles to recover and rebuild, making them stronger over time.

As for doing strength training on the same day as your runs, it's generally recommended to separate them by at least a few hours or do them on non-consecutive days. Here's why:

* **Running takes priority**: If you're doing a hard run, you want to make sure you're fully recovered and not fatigued from strength training.
* **Interference with running performance**: Strength training can temporarily decrease your running performance due to muscle fatigue. You want to be able to run at your best, especially during intense or long runs.
* **Increased risk of injury**: Combining strength training and running on the same day can increase your risk of injury, especially if you're new to strength training or running.

**Sample Schedule:**

Here's an example schedule:

* Monday: Easy run (30 minutes)
* Tuesday: Strength training (core, glutes, and legs)
* Wednesday: Rest day
* Thursday: Interval run (30 minutes)
* Friday: Strength training (core, glutes, and legs)
* Saturday: Long slow run (45 minutes)
* Sunday: Rest day or active recovery (e.g., yoga, walk, or light cross-training)

**Exceptions:**

If you're short on time, you can do strength training after an easy run, but make sure to:

* Keep the strength training session light and short (20-30 minutes)
* Focus on exercises that don't fatigue your legs too much (e.g., core and upper body exercises)
* Listen to your body and adjust as needed

Remember, consistency and patience are key. Stick to your schedule, and you'll see improvements in your running performance and overall fitness over time!
